topic.title: Secure Boot architecture

note.p: Remove in RevBThis feature is only available in the revision B switch

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic struct-d) (topic firmware-d) (topic pmcrevhis-d)
topic.title: Components

body.p: Secure boot is made up of a combination of hardware and firmware. The hardware consists of a Boot ROM which is immutable (cannot be changed), One-time programmable (OTP) memory, and SHA/RSA cryptography engines. The firmware consists of code to load images into device RAM and verify signatures of new images before allowing activation.
Switchtec employs the PKCS#1 (Public Key Cryptography Standard) v2.1 featuring:

li.p: SHA3-512 (Secure Hash Algorithm)
RSASSA-PSS (Probabilistic Signature Scheme) using 4096b keys

section.title: High level blocks used in secure boot
section.p: The design of Switchtec secure boot is built around extending trust from HW outwards to the FW. All items in silicon are immutable or non-rewritable. The following images in the SPI flash are either signed or protected by CRC32 as denoted by a lock symbol and a CRC32 icon below.

fig.title: High level blocks used in secure boot

table.title: High level blocks used in secure boot

entry.p: This is a boot loader built in silicon which is fundamentally immutable (cannot be changed)
One-time programmable memory (OTP) used to store security settings, KMSK, and other settings which cannot be overwritten
Key Manifest Sign Key (KMSK) is a region in OTP which stores up to four public key hashes for use in signing the key manifest in SPI flash
The Unique Device Secret (UDS) is a secret random generated assigned to each and every device as defined in the Trusted Computing Group (TCG) Device Identifier Composition Engine (DICE).
This is a descriptor stored in SPI flash and provides a table of contents listing of the locations of all other images in flash.
This is a small partition inside SPI flash which contains a list of public keys used for decrypting all the signed images in flash
This is the secondary boot loader which resides in SPI flash and handles the verification of the switch configuration and main firmware
This file contains customer specific switch configurations including bifurcation, PCIe partitions, and sideband configurations
This is the main FW image

section.title: OTP Registers
section.p: The One-time programmable memory is a hardware block in Switchtec that is initialized all zeros. OTP is programmed by electrically blowing a strip of metal or poly with a flow of high-density current using the I/O voltage supply (1.8V). Switchtec features an on-chip voltage for blowing these fuses which can be enabled via a fuse-blow firmware command. Once OTP memory is programmed, it cannot be reprogrammed. When referring to the OTP memory, we use the terms "blown" and "unblown" where "unblown" means the memory cell is not programmed and has a value of 0b. "Blown" means the memory cell is 1b.

entry.p: Set at customer manufacturing time or runtime
Write: once for BL1 or main FW
01b: Debug is disabled unless cryptographically enabled.

note.p: No user intervention required. The Boot Rom will set this field based on the EJTAG Access Setting.

entry.p: Write: once for BL1 or main FW
01b: Initialized unsecured. Can't be secured in the future.
10b: Initialized secure. Settings can't be updated.
This field can only be set via the Secure State set command.
Write: once for BL1 or main FW

Set to enable attestation process. If enabled symmetric key generation at each BL stage will be required to handoff keys/certificates between BLs. Enabling this will significantly extend the boot time.
Write: once for BL1 or main FW

This setting is set during the securing process and allows the user to define the state of the EJTAG port after the device is secured. This does not define the security state of the device itself but rather controls the state of the EJTAG port. EJTAG security settings
Setting
EJTAG in BL1
EJTAG in BL2
EJTAG in Main FW
0000b
enabled
enabled
enabled
0001b
locked
enabled
enabled
0011b
locked
locked
locked
0111b
disabled
see BL1 state
see BL1 state
1011b
locked
disabled
disabled
1111b
disabled
disabled
disabled

li.p: enabled - port is enabled
disabled - port is disabled but can be securely unlocked
locked - port is permanently disabled and cannot be securely unlocked

entry.p: Write: once for BL1 or main FW
Controls the SPI access rate for BL1
Write: once for BL1 or main FW

If BL1 enters TWI recovery mode due to the TWI recovery pin being set, BL1 will exit this recovery mode and continue to bootup after the timeout period specified in this register. Any input to TWI will stop this timeout mechanism and wait for user instruction.
This value is expressed in seconds (s). A value of 0000b means no timeout.
Write: once for BL1 or main FW
This register sets the TWI port used by BL1 for disaster recovery (this bus should not be shared with other devices)
Write: once for BL1 or main FW
Sets the TWI slave address of the recovery port (TWI_RECOVERY_ADDR[6:0])
This register controls the upper 5 bits of the TWI address field (bits 2 to 6) of a 7-bit TWI address.

TWI_RECOVERY_ADDR[1:0]: Set
must by BOOTSTRAP be 00b so that BOOT_STRAP[13:12] can be used to write these lower two bits.

p.ph: The TWI Slave Address is derived as follows:

li.p: TWI_RECOVERY_ADDR[6:0] | BOOTSTRAP[13:12]
(7-bit addressing)
(TWI_RECOVERY_ADDR[6:0] | BOOTSTRAP[13:12]) << 1
(8-bit addressing)
0x58 (7-bit addressing)
0xB0(8-bit addressing)

entry.p: No explicit checking is done on any other addresses applied here.
Write: once for BL1 or main FW

row.entry: Enables/Disables specific TWI commands for security. The first TWI command is Ping which is used to test TWI communication. Ping cannot be disabled.
Shared Public Key Exponent for all KSKM entries

entry.p: Set at customer manufacturing time or runtime
Write: BL1 or main FW, each array entry can only be written once.

They Key Manifest Sign Key is an entry in an array that stores up to four (4) 512 bit key hashes. If BL1 checks a hash against one entry in this array and the check fails, it will proceed to the next key in the array. This allows for new keys to be burned to KMSK and validated before the original key is revoked.
Keys can be written incrementally to allow transfer of ownership.

Secret random number assigned uniquely during manufacturing from a secure random number generator and should be unique to each device. Once this field is programmed it can only be accessed by BL1. This field is used by TCG DICE.
Walking 1 register to increment the index of KMSK entry index (this defines which KMSK index is valid)
Walking 1 register to increment the index of Key Manifest Partition security version
Walking 1 register to increment the version of BL2. Older versions of BL2 are revoked automatically when this is incremented.
Walking 1 register to increment the version of Main FW. Older versions of FW are revoked automatically when this is incremented.
Walking 1 register to increment the secure unlock version

note.p: The walking 1s register increment is intended to automatically invalidate prior images. There is a secure version field in the meta-data of each image. If, for example, a security issues is found in BL2 where the security version is 0x0002, a new BL2 can be built with a fix in place. This new BL2 will have an incremented security version of 0x0004. When BL1 boots up, BL1 compares the security version of BL2 in OTP with the security field in the BL2 image. If the value of the image is less than the one in OTP, it means the BL2 image is stale and should not be used.

entry.p: Set at customer manufacturing time or runtime
Once this bit is set, Security Settings Region is read-only.
Once this bit is set, security revocation feature is permanently disabled. Set this field when securing the switch.
Once the bit of corresponding KMSK array entry is set, this entry is read-only
RW or Read-only to BL1 control
Once these two bits are set, UDS region is read-only for BL1. Once exiting BL1, this region is inaccessible to FW

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic struct-d) (topic firmware-d) (topic pmcrevhis-d)
topic.title: Image format

body.p: Each Switchtec image contains similar meta-data which is added in the signing process and used in the validation process. There are three main image format types:

li.p: Partition map
Key Manifest
Image file

section.title: Partition map format
section.p: The partition map describes the location of all other images in flash. BL1 relies on this map to determine where the Key Manifest resides so it can use it to authenticate the other images.

section.title: Key manifest format
section.p: The Key Manifest contains the list of keys used to authenticate all other images in flash (BL2, Main FW, Configuration). The Key Manifest public key is validated against the active KMSK hash which is stored in OTP. The public keys stored in the Key Manifest correspond to signatures in the corresponding images (BL2, Main FW, configuration).

section.title: Image file format
section.p: Each image file contains a descriptor, public key, public key exponent, meta-data, signature, and the raw image data.

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic struct-d) (topic firmware-d) (topic pmcrevhis-d)
topic.title: Image validation

body.p: Switchtec follows a chain-of-trust method for extending trust from immutable blocks in silicon to mutable blocks in flash memory.

section.title: Sequence
section.p: When the switch is secured, a typical high level secure boot flow will take the following steps:

li.p: BL1 pulls the partition map from SPI flash and performs an integrity check (CRC32)
BL1 checks the OTP Security Field to see if secure boot is enabled, if it is not then run unsecure CRC checking of the images, if it is set then proceed.
BL1 reads the partition map for the location of the key manifest (this is the key store for all images in flash)
BL1 pulls the key manifest into RAM and performs a hash compare of the public key stored in the metadata of the key manifest against the public key stored in the KMSK
BL1 authenticates the signature in the key manifest against the public key stored in metadata
The key manifest is now trusted
BL1 copies BL2 into RAM
BL1 verifies the public key of the BL2 image file and performs a hash compare of the public key stored in the metadata against the key in the Key Manifest partition
BL1 authenticates the signature in the BL2 image against the public key stored in metadata
BL1 hands off execution to BL2
BL2 executes and repeats the process to pull switch configuration and FW image into RAM and compare against keys in the Key Manifest partition

section.title: Partition map validation
section.p: Switchtec performs a CRC32 validity check on the partition map. The partition map is a redundant partition. By default, Switchtec checks the sequence number of the two partitions in the partition map and uses a ping-pong scheme to select which one to load.

section.title: Key Manifest validation
section.p: The key manifest is validated by checking the validity (CRC32) of the Key Manifest image header and then proceeding to check the public key stored in the header against the KMSK.

section.title: BL2/Main FW/Configuration validation
section.p: After the key manifest is validated, BL1 will proceed to validate BL2 by checking the validity of the image (CRC32) and reading the public key from the header and comparing is against the corresponding entry in the Key Manifest Partition. BL1 then authenticates the signature in BL2 against the public key in the BL2 metadata. This is repeated for the Main FW and Configuration to extend trust to the firmware.

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic struct-d) (topic firmware-d) (topic pmcrevhis-d)
topic.title: Image redundancy

body.p: Switchtec supports image redundancy for failure mitigation. In the event where one image is corrupt, a backup image can be made available. Images can be marked as redundant in the partition map. There is an independent pointer to select which image (index 0 or index 1) and a separate pointer to mark whether the alternate index is redundant. The following figure shows and example where the primary image is in white, the redundant images are blue and non-redundant images are gray.

p.draft-comment: Need details on which images are loaded as primary vs secondary. Some images we try index 0 and if it fails we fall back to image 1. In other cases there is a active flag.

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic struct-d) (topic firmware-d) (topic pmcrevhis-d)
topic.title: Image signing

body.p: Switchtec security is based on a public/private key-pair which is generated by the platform vendor. The public key is used to sign images while the private key is kept secret by the platform vendor. Switchtec uses a 2-step signing process for all images. There are two operating modes: uninitialized and secure. In uninitialized state, all the security fields can be written but no checking and validation is performed.

section.title: Key generation
section.p: The signing process begins in an HSM where the customer generates a public/private key-pair where the private key remains in the HSM. A unique public/private key pair can be generated for each image type or a single key-pair can be used to sign all images. The following images are signed and validated when the switch is operating in secure mode.

li.p: Security Settings
KMSK
Key Manifest
BL2
Main Firmware
Switch Configuration

entry.p: ChipLink builds an unsigned image of the partition map
ChipLink provides a an interface to configure the security settings in OTP
ChipLink provides an interface to add public key hashes for burning to the OTP
ChipLink provides an interface to configure all switch settings and builds an unsigned image
This is an open source tool used to take in a list of public keys and build an unsigned image
BL2 is not normally modified, however for PSX/PAX customers, an unsigned BL2 image can be generated through this tool
For PSX/PAX customers, an unsigned Main FW image can be generated through this tool

note.p: 1 - The Switchtec Unsigned Image Generator (SUIG) is an open source image generation tool used to build various unsigned images which can be written to a switch running in unsecure mode or can be provided to the image signing tool.
2 - ChipLink is a debug, diagnostic, and configuration tool which is used in all of our data center products. More information on ChipLink can be found here: ChipLink.

entry.p: The image signing tool takes the unsigned images from the generation step and signs them with the signature provided by the HSM

note.p: 1 - The Switchtec Image Signing Tool (SIST) is an open source image signing tool used to take a secure signature from the HSM and add it to unsigned images. The tool is run in two steps:

li.p: Take the unsigned image and create a hash
Customer feeds the hash to their HSM which has the public key
HSM generates a signature
The tool is run again with the unsigned image and the signature to generate a signed image

example.title: Writing the security settings image to OTP
example.p: Security settings in Table 2 are committed to OTP via the Switchtec user space utility which is an open source utility available on Github. The utility will provide access to writing OTP registers (remember, these are permanent), one of which enables secure boot operation.

li.p: In ChipLink, configure the security settings registers to desired values
Write an unsigned binary
Provide the binary to switchtec_user to commit changes to the OTP

example.title: Writing the KMSK image to OTP
example.p: The Key Manifest Sign Key is a hash of the public key used to sign the Key Manifest Partition. The header of the Key Manifest partition contains the public key used to sign it. A hash of this public key is compared to the stored hash in the KMSK. There are two paths to writing KMSK to OTP.

p.b: Option 1: The device is operating uninitialized (and therefore unsecure)

li.p: In HSM, generate a public/private key pair for signing the Key Manifest Partition
Provide the public key to ChipLink to generate a hash of it and provide an unsigned binary
Take the resulting KMSK binary and use switchtec_user to commit to OTP

p.b: Option 2: The device is operating in secure mode (in this case, the switch must authenticate before allowing new KMSK to be added)

li.p: In HSM, generate a public/private key pair for signing the Key Manifest Partition
Provide the public key to ChipLink to generate a hash of it and provide an unsigned binary
Provide the unsigned binary to the Switchtec Image Signing Tool (SIST) along with the active public key already in the KMSK
MIST will provide an image hash
Provide this image hash to your HSM which will generate a signature for the image
Provide the unsigned binary from 2 along with the signature from 5 to produced a signed KMSK image
Take the resulting signed KMSK binary and use switchtec_user to commit to OTP

example.title: Writing the Key Manifest image to Flash
example.p: The Key Manifest contains a list of public keys used to authenticate the other images in flash (BL2, Config, FW). The Key Manifest is validated by BL1 against the KMSK.

li.p: In HSM, generate a public/private key pair for signing the Key Manifest Partition (same as the public key in KMSK example step 1)
Gather all the public keys used in all other images in flash: Key Manifest, BL2, Config, Main FW
Provide the list to the Switchtec Image Generation Tool (SIGT) along with a key manifest version (to invalidate older manifests)
MKGT will provide an unsigned Key Manifest image
Provide the unsigned Key Manifest image to the Switchtec Image Signing Tool (SIST) along with the Key Manifest public key
MIST will provide an image hash
Provide this image hash to your HSM which will generate a signature for the image
Provide the unsigned binary from 4 along with the signature from 7 to produced a signed Key Manifest image
Take the resulting signed Key Manifest binary and use switchtec_user to commit to flash

example.title: Writing the BL2 image to Flash
example.p: The BL2 image is nominally downloaded from the support portal (PFX) or built by the customer (PSX/PAX) and signed via the 2-step signing process outlined in Figure 10.

li.p: In HSM, generate a public/private key pair for signing the BL2
Provide the unsigned BL2 image from the portal (PFX) or development (PSX/PAX) to the Switchtec Image Signing Tool (SIST) along with the BL2 public key
MIST will provide an image hash
Provide this image hash to your HSM which will generate a signature for the image
Provide the unsigned binary from 2 along with the signature from 4 to produced a signed BL2 image
Take the resulting signed BL2 binary and use switchtec_user to commit to flash

example.title: Writing the Main FW image to Flash
example.p: The Main FW image is nominally downloaded from the support portal (PFX) or built by the customer (PSX/PAX) and signed via the 2-step signing process outlined in Figure 10.

li.p: In HSM, generate a public/private key pair for signing the Main FW
Provide the unsigned Main FW image from the portal (PFX) or development (PSX/PAX) to the Switchtec Image Signing Tool (SIST) along with the Main FW public key
MIST will provide an image hash
Provide this image hash to your HSM which will generate a signature for the image
Provide the unsigned binary from 2 along with the signature from 4 to produced a signed Main FW image
Take the resulting signed Main FW binary and use switchtec_user to commit to flash

example.title: Writing the Configuration image to Flash
example.p: The configuration file is generated by ChipLink and signed via the 2-step signing process outlined in Figure 10.

li.p: In HSM, generate a public/private key pair for signing the switch configuration
Provide the unsigned configuration image from the portal (PFX) or development (PSX/PAX) to the Switchtec Image Signing Tool (SIST) along with the configuration public key
MIST will provide an image hash
Provide this image hash to your HSM which will generate a signature for the image
Provide the unsigned binary from 2 along with the signature from 4 to produced a signed Configuration image
Take the resulting signed Configuration binary and use switchtec_user to commit to flash

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic struct-d) (topic firmware-d) (topic pmcrevhis-d)
topic.title: Key Revocation

body.p: Switchtec supports key revocation. The following table captures some examples of why key revocation is required for each image type.

row.entry: Private key of key-pair for key manifest has become untrusted (compromised or lost)

entry.p: There are a total of four (4) KMSK keys in the device OTP. This means a secure KMSK key can be revoked no more than 3 times. It is critical for customers to protect the private key used to generate the key-hash in the KMSK.

If a new key manifest signed image is burned to flash, BL1 will check the current KMSK key against the public key in the key manifest. If they do not match, BL1 will try the next KMSK entry. If the next one matches, the previous KMSK entries are revoked.
ChipLink is used to build a new KMSK binary for burning to device OTP

row.entry: Private key of key-pair for BL2, Main FW, or Switch configuration has become untrusted (compromised or lost)

entry.p: The key manifest resides in flash, however the Key Manifest security version is stored in device OTP. There are a total of twelve (12) Key Manifest versions.

Burning a new Key Manifest with a new security version to flash results in a corresponding increment to the Key Manifest security version in OTP. Key Manifest images signed with an older security version are revoked when this happens.
Switchtec Unsigned Image Tool is used to build a new Key Manifest image signed with the new public key. As an argument to this tool, the customer also specified the Key Manifest version.
If the Key Manifest version is updated in the image, the device OTP will be updated with the new version.

row.entry: A critical security bug is found in BL2

entry.p: The BL2 resides in flash, however the BL2 security version is stored in OTP. There are a total of sixteen (16) BL2 security versions.

Burning a BL2 with a new security version to flash results in a corresponding increment to the BL2 security version in OTP. BL2 images signed with an older security version are revoked when this happens.
Switchtec Unsigned Image Tool is used to build a new image signed with the new public key. As an argument to this tool, the customer also specify the security version.
If the security version is updated in the image, the device OTP will be updated with the new version.

row.entry: A critical security bug is found in Main FW / Switch Configuration

entry.p: The Main FW and Switch Configuration resides in flash, however the security versions for these images are stored in OTP. There are a total of thirty-two (32) security versions for each image type: Main FW and Switch Configuration
Burning an image with a new security version to flash results in a corresponding increment to the security version in OTP. Images signed with an older security version are revoked when this happens.
Switchtec Unsigned Image Tool is used to build a new image signed with the new public key. As an argument to this tool, the customer also specify the security version.
If the security version is updated in the image, the device OTP will be updated with the new version.

topic.domains: (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic struct-d) (topic firmware-d) (topic pmcrevhis-d)
topic.title: Debugging secured devices

body.p: For Switchtec devices that are running in secure mode ( Secure State = 10b), devices can be configured where the EJTAG debug port can be locked out as per the EJTAG settings . In cases where customers need to debug a secured device, a secure unlock option is available.
The EJTAG debug port can be unlocked on a secured device by reading the following and generating a hash using the Switchtec Image Signing Tool (SIST).

li.p: Device Serial Number
Secure unlock version of all the images in the Key Manifest
Public key hash used to sign the Key Manifest (active KMSK entry)

body.p: MIST will provide a hash which can be provided to the HSM. Customers can use the has from MIST and the public key hash of the active KMSK to identify the matching private key-pair in the HSM to use to provide a signature. This signature is then provided to the MRPC command used to request a HW port unlock. If the signature matches, the EJTAG port in the switch will be unlocked.

note.p: Additional notes on HW unlocking a port:

li.p: The signature generated in this process will only work for this specific device since the signature is tied to the device serial number
When the HW port is unlocked, it will stay unlocked through RSTB. However, the unlock will not persist on a power cycle or over a test access reset (TRSTB)
